awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A Hybrid Local-Nonlocal Peridynamics Framework to Model  Failure Across Deformations and Strain Rates
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) grant supports fundamental research on modeling fracture processes in materials and structures. Due to the several types of loading that can induce failure, these problems span a broad spectrum of coupled physical phenomena, deformations, loading rates, and length scales, where physical testing is often limited and costly. Current computational methods provide viable means but have their limitations in accurately and robustly performing failure simulations across all considerations. This research will innovate by developing novel algorithms that overcome these limitations by combining the advantages offered by existing computational techniques. Consequently, this research will allow investigations of dynamic fracture, complex three-dimensional failure modes, and damage initiation and propagation, thus accelerating the understanding of the science behind these events. Engineering applications of this work include mitigation of disasters and deterioration of infrastructure, and advances in diverse areas such as additive manufacturing, tool wear, and biomechanics. The educational portion of this program will develop open courses that will aid in learning the fundamentals of the knowledge and disseminating the results. The learning material and research will be integrated with an outreach program for underrepresented undergraduate and graduate students, to recruit, retain, and train the next generation of engineers in simulation-based analysis.

Effective approaches for simulating three-dimensional complex fracture has been a long-standing challenge. To overcome this challenge, the main objective of this research is to achieve a unification of the local classical reproducing kernel meshfree method and the nonlocal peridynamics method, to form the hybrid reproducing kernel peridynamics (RKPD) framework. This unification is intended to enhance several critical features in the non-local approach, necessary for effective numerical analysis of complex failure problems across a wide range of deformations and deformation rates: high accuracy and optimal convergence, ease of integration of multiple physical processes, high-order accurate shock wave propagation, and contact mechanics. The framework will be tested and validated against data obtained from experiments on a nanosilica reinforced epoxy composite, possessing a complex microstructure. Moreover, these computational developments will be incorporated into an open-source software that will be freely available to the science and engineering communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

This research project focused on advancing computational methodologies to model the failure of materials and complex microstructures under various loading conditions, including biomaterials, wave propagation, contact, and large deformations. The goal was to enhance the understanding of fracture mechanics and structural failure in engineering applications, while also training students in advanced numerical methods and programming. The outcomes of this work are expected to have broad applications in engineering design, material science, and industries requiring high-performance simulations.

Key Achievements:

The project made significant progress in developing new computational techniques and software for simulating complex material behaviors, such as fracture in composite materials and two-phase flow dynamics. We successfully modeled fracture mechanics in layered materials and explored how internal frictional properties can influence material toughness. This research has the potential to inform the design of more resilient materials, including bio-inspired composites, which are used in industries such as aerospace, automotive, and energy. Our efforts also involved applying machine learning techniques to accelerate the simulation of material behaviors. These innovations have the potential to greatly reduce computational costs, making high-fidelity simulations more accessible for real-world engineering problems. These breakthroughs in simulation speed and accuracy will be valuable for industries that rely on advanced material design, including energy sectors like fracking and geothermic energy, where fracture behavior in complex environments plays a key role in performance.

Impact on Science and Technology:

The project’s methodologies significantly improve how engineers can model and predict the behavior of materials under extreme conditions, such as large deformations and rapid loading. The integration of machine learning into material simulation is especially impactful, as it enables faster, more efficient solutions to complex problems that would have been computationally prohibitive in the past. In addition, the research demonstrated that by modulating the frictional properties within layered composites, the toughness of these materials can be enhanced, which is particularly relevant to the design of materials used in challenging engineering applications. The work in composite materials and the development of new discretization methods for fracture modeling represent important contributions to the fields of material science and structural engineering.

Training and Development:

Throughout the course of the project, several students were trained and mentored in advanced computational techniques, including four Ph.D. students who gained expertise in phase-field modeling, fracture analysis, and the integration of machine learning with traditional methods. Two undergraduate students completed an Honors Thesis focusing on the use of machine learning to improve composite material analysis, further integrating innovative techniques into the curriculum. This project has contributed to the professional growth of a new generation of engineers and researchers, equipping them with the skills needed to tackle some of the most pressing challenges in modern engineering and material science.

Broader Societal Impact:

The tools and methods developed in this project have a direct societal impact by addressing key challenges in material design and failure prediction. The reduction in computational costs and the ability to more accurately simulate material behavior under extreme conditions will help make engineering processes more efficient and sustainable. These advancements could improve the safety, performance, and durability of critical infrastructure and materials used in industries like aerospace, automotive, and energy. Moreover, the project's focus on mentoring underrepresented students, including women and students with ADHD, has contributed to the diversification of the STEM workforce. Emphasizing inclusive education and professional development, the project has ensured that a broader range of talented individuals are equipped to contribute to these innovative fields.
